replies.body: As someone who plays this game for leisure and fun, not really as much for the competitive aspect I am SO EXCITED for this.  For the collectors and the "completionists" out there, it will be a game within the game to "master" each champion.  Although I understand people's concerns with the word mastery being a slight misnomer given that it isn't entirely correlated with being "good" at a champion, I think this adds a ton of fun to the game by providing new goals for long time players.  +1 Riot!

Very similar feelings here.  I am not a Ranked person, but I would like to earn mastery on some of my favourite/best champions and this gives me a goal to aim for.  My PvP isn't just for fun anymore, it's also going to have a purpose and I'll get better all the while.

On the initial announcement, Riot Socrates said this in the comments:
> There are no demotions planned currently. This isn't intended to be a ranked system in the same sense as leagues. The grading system does give players an idea of how they are improving with a champion via the per game performance evaluation. Also, performance and winning or losing does dramatically affect gains, so a high performing player will unlock rewards much more quickly.

I feel like you may be confusing Masteries (like 21-9-0 stuff) with this. Though I guess they use the same name, so it's a bit understandable.

Maybe a better way to describe the new system would be "Champion Skill Tracker"

I'm pretty 100% certain this has **Absolutely nothing** to do with your mastery pages or summoner level or anything like that: I think it just says "Hey, here's how well you're doing with this particular champion" and nothing else, with purely cosmetic rewards (As opposed to mastery pages, which DO affect gameplay a bit).

So you don't have to 'level up' a champion to make them stronger or to access mastery pages or anything like that.

It's just a way to say "You're doing this well with this champion."

This is clearly an interesting concept, but I still am confused. Will you or will you not view our games? Or will you use variables on game performance? Or maybe knows their way around the spells and builds for the champion? Or merely win rate?

Riot will definitely NOT be viewing each game. League of legends has over 27 million active players each day, that's 2.7 million games per day. If each game lasted 30 minutes long and Riot's employees worked 24 hours a day, 24 hours/30 minutes per game = 48, 2.7 million/48 game per employee = 56,250 employees. Let's say that each employee worked at Riot in California and was each payed minimum wage, 56,250 * $9 * 24 hours in a day= $12,150,000. It would cost Riot over 12 million dollars a day for them to watch and rate each player's match. This is paying them minimum wage and having them work 24 hours a day without medical.
